title: Meaningful Counterplay
body:
So Riot has been telling us recently that they're all about creating meaningful counterplay, and while I think they've done a mostly alright job on this front there are things that are being done that just don't fit that philosophy, whether it's due to random stats being tacked on to them or just a lack of real counterplay options in their gameplay patterns.

{{champion:157}}  I think this guy qualifies as one of the top dogs in the random stats department. Doubled crit chance and a crapload of arpen tacked onto his ultimate just make him a pain to deal with with no real drawbacks for him. However, I find his gameplay patterns to be mostly alright. His ease of farming in lane due to his manaless-ness can be a bit problematic but I think overall his big problems are that bonus arpen and crit chance, making itemizing vs him incredibly difficult while not adding any meaningful counterplay elements.

{{champion:134}} {{champion:45}} {{champion:1}} {{champion:127}} All seem to suffer from the gameplay pattern of "either they have banshee's or QSS and they live or they don't and they die". The whole burst mage concept SHOULD exist, and can exist beautifully in champions such as {{champion:99}} {{champion:101}} (both champions have a dodgeable skillshot that sets up the rest of their kits to do damage, which is a HEALTHY GAMEPLAY ELEMENT imo), but tacking on a, for all intents and purposes unavoidable, stun just makes it feel like there's only one thing you can do to survive or nothing at all. Veigar especially would become a huge problem and be immediately nerfed if everyone realized how strong he is. These champions do have drawbacks in their relative immobility and mana pools but at the same time are played in such a way that they're either overbearing or worthless- not really fun for anybody.

{{champion:84}} {{champion:19}} Both have random heals tacked onto their kits. Both have entirely point and click gameplay patterns. Both are unhealthy in their current states. Nuff said.

{{champion:150}} Another ball of stats champion with HUGE utility in his kit. Hell, his transformation in and of itself is an unhealthy gameplay mechanic. For the 15 seconds or whatever that he's transformed almost nobody can go toe to toe with him, especially in laning, thereby reducing any chance of fighting back against him in that state. Then he becomes a ranged champion with a great escape! There's just no winning vs this guy. 

{{champion:64}} While I love Lee Sin dearly, he IS rather problematic. He shares this problem with {{champion:236}} in that both of them give everything you could want in a jungler or marksman, respectively. Their kits are just too well rounded. Not to mention {{champion:64}}  also has a bunch of random ass stats just popped into his kit willy nilly. Spellvamp, Lifesteal, Bonus AS, incredibly high base ad and some of the best utility in the game mean something has to be done about {{champion:64}} 

I hope Riot gets around to addressing some of these champions at some point or another. Whether they get random stat bonuses that are poor gameplay elements on their own or just have their own play patterns that don't make for interesting champion interactions, the key points I addressed here are big problems with the way League of Legends is being played.

replies.body: Riot only wants older champions to have counterplay. Their newer releases seem free to ignore any and all design principles they claim to hold.

Like.. who? Working backwards

{{champion:421}} strong in the jungle, so-so top lane. Top lane Reki especially hates anyone with any form of hard engage. Darius, Riven, Pantheon, etc. If she burrows to try and heal, punish her for it. She can barely fight back in that form.

{{champion:429}} Strong against immobile melees, but is absolutely crushed by most other adcs, not to mention assassins. 

{{champion:268}} Immobile mage. If he sends his soldiers out to poke, he has no escape. If he keeps them close to farm, he can't poke.

{{champion:150}} Mini gnar is THE squishiest champion around. He loses to both sustained poke and all-ins. Some champs can even go toe-to-toe with mega gnar, at least early game. 

{{champion:201}} Entirely defense based champion, no real offense capabilities to speak of. 

{{champion:161}} Probably needs so explanation.

{{champion:157}} Horrible early game. Play to your tempo, not his, and you should be able to poke him down, if not kill him, very very quickly. Even Yasuo is not much of a threat if behind. 

I can go on, but I think you get the picture. Counterplay isn't as simple anymore as 'Dodge the blitz hook' or 'Don't group up if they have a Malphite'. It requires some thinking now. And if people have a problem with that, then the issue is on them.

{{champion:421}} You can't touch her do to her hard disengage by traveling through multiple tunnels until she feels she can fight you

{{champion:429}} Strong against anyone with skillshots and unless you have a leona already on top of her you have no hope of catching her. A capable support completely makes up for her lack of 1v1, I hope you realize 2 portions of her kits rely on having a teammate.

{{champion:268}} Long range micro management with low cooldown on soldiers. You aren't going to be overextended without some form of escape. Can Q soldiers to a distance and jump to them and if you still get past can wall them off himself.

{{champion:150}} Mini gnar also has extreme kite with escapes and hybrid % damage and movespeed in the same ability

{{champion:201}} Braum can absolutely play offense with the amount of cc this guy has. He just has to Q you and they can all in and proc stun while you are slowed

{{champion:161}} Decent poke and zone, but is ANTI-all in. If you all in him he has the most strength, he has trouble all-inning you though if you are above 70% hp

{{champion:157}} He has a ridiculous trading ability at any point in the game, and with the right rune page can be an extreme threat if he gets a kill at 5 minutes, which isn't hard with his dashing capabilities and trading. Yasuo is most definitely a threat if behind, I don't think you get DOUBLE CRIT CHANCE, meaning it takes HALF the time for him to catch up than any other crit chance champion in the game.

If you'd like, I can pull up a handy list of champions that just laugh at Yasuo early game. Also, you're entirely missing the point of double crit. Crit doesn't mean anything unless you have the damage to back it up. What will hit harder, a person who constantly hits for 5 damage or a person who hits for 2 damage, doubled by crits? All shiv does is make it easier for him to farm and harass. Until he gets some actual damage behind him, he's still not the biggest issue.

You list all of these newer champs with whom the counterplay usually amounts to "catch them out when they're dumb" and then I look at Sion whose Q needs to charge for 2 seconds and Cassiopeia who is not allowed to have a reliable ult because counterplay despite being locked out of the game pre-30 minutes due to her passive.

I have counter play against Sion in virtually everything he does. I can shut down Cass simply by roaming and turning around (whether on purpose or accidentally) when she ults. My counterplay to Azir is "stay far away unless he's dumb and burns his escape and his ult and I'm OK to take significant damage". I'm not buying the "new champs have just as much counterplay" thing. And how Gnar loses to poke when his poke outranges virtually everyone and he can hop away from poke himself is beyond me. Kalista may not do as much damage as most ADCs when her support sucks but that doesn't mean she isn't ridiculously good against skill shot mages and anything melee. Yasuo can't even be itemised against if the game doesn't end by 20 minutes.

Braum and Vel'Koz have fine counterplay. Vel is a standard mage with mediocre CC and a channeled ult of all things and Braum's projectile shield is a well-made Windwall. Everything since them, not so much.

> 
> Then I look at Sion whose Q needs to charge for 2 seconds and Cassiopeia who is not allowed to have a reliable ult because counterplay despite being locked out of the game pre-30 minutes due to her passive. I can shut down Cass simply by roaming and turning around (whether on purpose or accidentally) when she ults.
> 

Sion was designed to be an old school bruiser-tank. As in: "You know he's coming but you won't be able to do anything about him." (Pre-nerf Jax, anyone?) It's true too, he has pretty decent objective control.

You can roam on plenty of champs, problem is that CS is too rewarding. The few times I've seen Cassiopeia, her late game twin fang spam was the threat. Having her ult as a slow is enough for that.

Gnar has a huge poke but his escape has a high cooldown and you can force him not to catch his boomerang, it forces the skill on a really high CD. Mega gnar has a really low sustained damage, so if you avoid his skills or survive his combo you can actually kill him. When you want him to be ganked make him burn his jump then start the gank with the jungler.
New Sion was a new release, though, and he has the most counterplay out of ANY champion, IMO.

{{champion:45}} Idea:

Passive/Q stays the same.
W gives a large slow for a short amount of time, maybe followed by a small slow (5%-10%) for around 5 seconds to give him a little chasing ability.
E is a 1/1.5 second channel.
R becomes an AP + Mana steal from an enemy champion.

Veigar should still have roughly the same burst except he wouldn't just delete people who build AP, but still follow the Q-stacking, mage counter theme that he is.

The mages listed by OP are perfect in every way and deserve to be nerfed (especially Veigar). Lux and Xerath are fine the way they are, because it's actually possible to dodge their skillshots. With Veigar, even if he misses his stun, you're still trapped inside the box, so he is REWARDED for missing a skillshot. Doesn't make a lot of sense. And I'm not going to accept mobility as a weakness, because they can just get boots and it fixes that problem. And boots of mobility is an EXTREMELY cheap item. Meanwhile the item needed to counter them costs about 1600 gold.
